query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
1 Nel tempo che Iunone era crucciata 2 per Semelè contra ’l sangue tebano, 3 come mostrò una e altra fïata,
4 Atamante divenne tanto insano, 5 che veggendo la moglie con due figli 6 andar carcata da ciascuna mano,
7 gridò: «Tendiam le reti, sì ch’io pigli 8 la leonessa e ’ leoncini al varco»; 9 e poi distese i dispietati artigli,
10 prendendo l’un ch’avea nome Learco, 11 e rotollo e percosselo ad un sasso; 12 e quella s’annegò con l’altro carco.
query.result:
**English:**
1 At the time when Juno was angered 2 against Semele and the Theban blood, 3 as she showed on more than one occasion,
4 Athamas became so mad 5 that, seeing his wife with two children 6 walking burdened on each hand,
7 he cried: "Let's spread the nets, so that I may catch 8 the lioness and the lion cubs at the pass"; 9 and then he stretched out his pitiless claws,
10 seizing the one whose name was Learchus, 11 and he whirled him around and dashed him against a rock; 12 and she drowned herself with the other burden.
**Cornish:**
1 Yn termyn pan veu Juno yn krusys 2 rag Semelè orth an gans Theban, 3 avel henna a wrug diskwedhes moy es termyn,
4 Athamas a dheuth ken fethys, 5 wosa henna dhe weles y wraga gans dew bub 6 ow tos ow holghas war y dhewlagas,
7 ev a leveris: "Ledhon an rosow, marow henna yth allav 8 dhe gemeres an leones ha'n leonow byghan orth an fordh"; 9 ha wosa henna ev a ledyas y artel gans kreulder,
10 ow kemer an unn a veu y hanow Learco, 11 ha ev a'n troellys ha'n tasys orth unn garrek; 12 ha henna a wrug negya y honen gans an karga aral.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
13 E quando la fortuna volse in basso 14 l’altezza de’ Troian che tutto ardiva, 15 sì che ’nsieme col regno il re fu casso,
16 Ecuba trista, misera e cattiva, 17 poscia che vide Polissena morta, 18 e del suo Polidoro in su la riva
19 del mar si fu la dolorosa accorta, 20 forsennata latrò sì come cane; 21 tanto il dolor le fé la mente torta.
query.result:
**English:**
13 And when fortune cast down 14 the greatness of the Trojans, who dared all, 15 so that together with the kingdom the king was overthrown,
16 Hecuba, sad, wretched and miserable, 17 after she saw Polyxena dead, 18 and on the shore of the sea
19 the sorrowful woman became aware of her Polydorus, 20 she barked like a dog, mad with grief; 21 so much did her sorrow twist her mind.
**Cornish:**
13 Ha pan wrug an forton troha dhe isel 14 ughelder an Trojanow a veu owth ow holghas, 15 marow henna gans an ryalta an myghtern a veu owth ow thul,
16 Ecuba trist, meskin ha truan, 17 wosa henna dhe weles Polissena marow, 18 ha war glann an mor
19 an venen dolurus a veu owth owth ow kolwel, 20 a latras avel ki, ow fethys gans dolur; 21 ken moy an dolur a wrug troha y spyrys.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
22 Ma né di Tebe furie né troiane 23 si vider mäi in alcun tanto crude, 24 non punger bestie, nonché membra umane,
25 quant’ io vidi in due ombre smorte e nude, 26 che mordendo correvan di quel modo 27 che ’l porco quando del porcil si schiude.
query.result:
**English:**
22 But neither Theban nor Trojan Furies 23 were ever seen so cruel in any place, 24 not even tearing at beasts, let alone human limbs,
25 as I saw in two pale and naked shades, 26 who ran biting in the same way 27 as a pig when it bursts out of the sty.
**Cornish:**
22 Mes na veu furyow Theban na Trojan 23 bythkweth owth ow weles ken fethys, 24 na bestys owth ow pungi, let alone esel an dus,
25 avel henna owth owth ow weles yn dew kevriji pal ha noeth, 26 a veu owth ow resek ow pungi yn an fordh henna 27 avel an porgh pan ev a dheuth magh a'n porghkott.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
28 L’una giunse a Capocchio, e in sul nodo 29 del collo l’assannò, sì che, tirando, 30 grattar li fece il ventre al fondo sodo.
query.result:
**English:**
28 One reached Capocchio, and at the nape 29 of his neck he seized him, so that, pulling, 30 he made him scrape his belly on the hard ground.
**Cornish:**
28 Onan a dheuth dhe Capocchio, ha war an golon 29 a'y gewyn, dell wosa, ow tynna, 30 ow holya y'n golon war an tressa kalet.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
31 E l’Aretin che rimase, tremando 32 mi disse: «Quel folletto è Gianni Schicchi, 33 e va rabbioso altrui così conciando».
query.result:
**English:**
31 And the Aretine, who remained, trembling, 32 said to me: "That imp is Gianni Schicchi, 33 and he goes about thus tormenting others".
**Cornish:**
31 Ha'n Aretin a veu, ow tos ow tressa, 32 a leveris dhym: "An follet na yw Gianni Schicchi, 33 ha mos ow tos ow kensa neb arall".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
34 «Oh», diss’ io lui, «se l’altro non ti ficchi 35 li denti a dosso, non ti sia fatica 36 a dir chi è, pria che di qui si spicchi».
query.result:
**English:**
34 "Oh," I said to him, "if the other one doesn't sink 35 his teeth into your back, don't be troubled 36 to tell me who he is, before he leaves here".
**Cornish:**
34 "Oh," me a leveris dhodho, "mar nag asa'n follet arall 35 y'n dansow dhe'th gevelyn, na wra gonis 36 rag leverel dhym, kyns es ow partia".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
37 Ed elli a me: «Quell’ è l’anima antica 38 di Mirra scellerata, che divenne 39 al padre, fuor del dritto amore, amica.
query.result:
**English:**
37 And he to me: "That is the ancient soul 38 of the wicked Myrrha, who became 39 her father's mistress, in a love that was wrong.
**Cornish:**
37 Ha dhodho dhym: "Hena yw an eneval hen 38 a Virra an drog, a dheuth dhe vos 39 dhe'y thas, mes a'y karanteth, ow serch".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
40 Questa a peccar con esso così venne, 41 falsificando sé in altrui forma, 42 come l’altro che là sen va, sostenne,
43 per guadagnar la donna de la torma, 44 falsificare in sé Buoso Donati, 45 testando e dando al testamento norma».
query.result:
**English:**
40 She came to sin with him in this way, 41 disguising herself in another's form, 42 as the other one who is leaving there endured,
43 in order to gain the lady of the tower, 44 disguising himself as Buoso Donati, 45 making a will and giving it legal form.
**Cornish:**
40 Hi a dheuth dhe begi ganso gans an fordh na, 41 ow chanjya y honan dhe furv arall, 42 dell an arall a veu ow partia, ow godhes,
43 rag gwaynya benen an tora, 44 ow chanjya y honan dhe furv Buoso Donati, 45 ow skrifa testament ha'y rei dhe furv legel".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
46 E poi che i due rabbiosi fuor passati 47 sovra cu’ io avea l’occhio tenuto, 48 rivolsilo a guardar li altri mal nati.
query.result:
**English:**
46 And after the two rabid ones had passed 47 over whom I had kept my eye, 48 I turned to look at the other ill-born ones.
**Cornish:**
46 Ha wosa an dhew rabbus o veu partia 47 war-tu ow kovsa y'm lagha y'm golwg, 48 y'm droessa dhe wul an erel drog genys.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
49 Io vidi un, fatto a guisa di lëuto, 50 pur ch’elli avesse avuta l’anguinaia 51 tronca da l’altro che l’uomo ha forcuto.
query.result:
**English:**
49 I saw one, made in the likeness of a lion, 50 except that he had his loins 51 cut off by the other, who has man's fork.
**Cornish:**
49 Y'm gwelas onan, gwres dhe furv lew, 50 mes ow kovsa ev ow kodha 51 ow tronkya gans an arall, neb ow kodha forkek dhe dhen.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
52 La grave idropesì, che sì dispaia 53 le membra con l’omor che mal converte, 54 che ’l viso non risponde a la ventraia,
55 faceva lui tener le labbra aperte 56 come l’etico fa, che per la sete 57 l’un verso ’l mento e l’altro in sù rinverte.
query.result:
**English:**
52 The grievous dropsy, that so disfigures 53 the limbs with the humour that it badly converts, 54 so that the face does not match the belly,
55 made him hold his lips open 56 like the hectic man does, who because of thirst 57 turns one lip towards his chin and the other upwards.
**Cornish:**
52 An dropezi poes, a wra dhefurmya 53 an esel gans an omor a wra dhefurvya drog, 54 mar nag o kovsa an fas dhe'n golon,
55 a wra ow holya y'n gavasow ager, 56 dell an den a wra dhefurvya gans an seti, 57 ow trohe onan gavas dhe'y varv ha'n arall dhe'y wel.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
58 «O voi che sanz’ alcuna pena siete, 59 e non so io perché, nel mondo gramo», 60 diss’ elli a noi, «guardate e attendete
61 a la miseria del maestro Adamo; 62 io ebbi, vivo, assai di quel ch’i’ volli, 63 e ora, lasso!, un gocciol d’acqua bramo.
query.result:
**English:**
58 "O you who are without any pain, 59 and I know not why, in this wretched world," 60 he said to us, "look and pay attention
61 to the misery of Master Adam; 62 I had, when alive, plenty of what I wanted, 63 and now, alas!, I crave a drop of water.
**Cornish:**
58 "O why a wra heb marow poen, 59 ha nag ow kovsa pyth, yn an bys drog," 60 a leveris dhym dhin, "wulwel ha preder
61 dhe'n boesder a'n Mestr Adamo; 62 y'm bewnas, byw, kaletter a'm karas, 63 ha lemmyn, alas!, y'm karas rag onan dowr dhyw".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
64 Li ruscelletti che d’i verdi colli 65 del Casentin discendon giuso in Arno, 66 faccendo i lor canali freddi e molli,
67 sempre mi stanno innanzi, e non indarno, 68 ché l’imagine lor vie più m’asciuga 69 che ’l male ond’ io nel volto mi discarno.
query.result:
**English:**
64 The little streams that from the green hills 65 of Casentino descend down into Arno, 66 making their channels cool and soft,
67 are always before me, and not in vain, 68 for their image dries me up even more 69 than the sickness from which I am wasting away in my face.
**Cornish:**
64 An dowrow byghan a wra dheuth a'n brynn gwer 65 a Gasentin dhe'n avon Arno, 66 ow kul y'n kanolyow fres ha melyon,
67 yw bythkweth ow tos ow kensa, ha nag yw yn van, 68 rag y'n jurneth ow'm sechi moy ages 69 ages an cleves ow'm ow kul yn y'm fas.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
70 La rigida giustizia che mi fruga 71 tragge cagion del loco ov’ io peccai 72 a metter più li miei sospiri in fuga.
query.result:
**English:**
70 The strict justice that searches me out 71 draws its cause from the place where I sinned 72 to put my sighs more to flight.
**Cornish:**
70 An kethvos splannder a'm gorra 71 a wra dhe reson a'm pechas 72 rag dhe gorra'm anavalow dhe fleghes.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
73 Ivi è Romena, là dov’ io falsai 74 la lega suggellata del Batista; 75 per ch’io il corpo sù arso lasciai.
query.result:
**English:**
73 There is Romena, where I falsified 74 the league sealed by the Baptist; 75 because of which I left my body burned above.
**Cornish:**
73 Eno Romena, le may feals 74 an kevrans selys an Vatist; 75 rag henna'm gweles ow korf loskys.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
76 Ma s’io vedessi qui l’anima trista 77 di Guido o d’Alessandro o di lor frate, 78 per Fonte Branda non darei la vista.
query.result:
**English:**
76 But if I saw here the sad soul 77 of Guido or of Alessandro or of their brother, 78 I would not give up the sight for Fonte Branda.
**Cornish:**
76 Mes agensa gweles ama an eneval trist 77 a Guido po Alessandro po aga broder, 78 vythfyn Fonte Branda vythfyn an golwg.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
79 Dentro c’è l’una già, se l’arrabbiate 80 ombre che vanno intorno dicon vero; 81 ma che mi val, c’ho le membra legate?
82 S’io fossi pur di tanto ancor leggero 83 ch’i’ potessi in cent’ anni andare un’oncia, 84 io sarei messo già per lo sentiero,
85 cercando lui tra questa gente sconcia, 86 con tutto ch’ella volge undici miglia, 87 e men d’un mezzo di traverso non ci ha.
query.result:
**English:**
79 Inside there is already one of them, if the 80 angry shades that go around are telling the truth; 81 but what good is it to me, since my limbs are bound?
82 If only I were still so light 83 that I could go an inch in a hundred years, 84 I would already be set on the path,
85 searching for him among these vile people, 86 even though it goes around eleven miles, 87 and there is less than half a day's journey across it.
**Cornish:**
79 Mes yma'n onan a-berth, mar an 80 skevisow tewlel a wra a-dro, a lever gwir; 81 mes pyth yw dhymm, gan ow esel kethres?
82 Mar vythfyn vythfyn ow bys vythfyn golow, 83 henna vythfyn gallosek metya en kans blydhen mos a-dro un ons, 84 vythfyn vythfyn ow pos dhe setya war an fordh,
85 ow hwilas dhodho yntra an bobel-ma, 86 pub tra veur dres unnek mildir, 87 ha le ages han hanter dydh dhe'n fordh.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
88 Io son per lor tra sì fatta famiglia; 89 e’ m’indussero a batter li fiorini 90 ch’avevan tre carati di mondiglia».
query.result:
**English:**
88 I am among such a family for them; 89 and they led me to counterfeit the florins 90 that had three carats of alloy.
**Cornish:**
88 Y'm myskynn yntra aga teulu, 89 ha aga gorra dhe wul dhe'n florinys 90 o perthi tri karat a vondigel.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
91 E io a lui: «Chi son li due tapini 92 che fumman come man bagnate ’l verno, 93 giacendo stretti a’ tuoi destri confini?».
query.result:
**English:**
91 And I to him: "Who are the two wretches 92 who smoke like wet hands in winter, 93 lying huddled at your right confines?".
**Cornish:**
91 Ha my dh'agan: "Pwy yw an dhew bennans 92 a wra a-smokya kepar dhew dhorn wlyb y'n gwav, 93 ow pos dhe gorfos dhe'th kyns dhe dhe dhew?"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
94 «Qui li trovai—e poi volta non dierno—», 95 rispuose, «quando piovvi in questo greppo, 96 e non credo che dieno in sempiterno.
query.result:
**English:**
94 "Here I found them—and then they did not turn—", 95 he answered, "when I fell into this ditch, 96 and I do not think they will ever turn.
**Cornish:**
94 "Ama y'm kavos aga—ha nyns yw aga dro dhe'n fordh—", 95 ev a lever, "pan a-gryjyas y'n an greppa ma, 96 ha nyns yw kredis vythfyn aga dro byth."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
97 L’una è la falsa ch’accusò Gioseppo; 98 l’altr’ è ’l falso Sinon greco di Troia: 99 per febbre aguta gittan tanto leppo».
query.result:
**English:**
97 One is the false woman who accused Joseph; 98 the other is the false Greek Sinon of Troy: 99 with sharp fever they spew out such filth.
**Cornish:**
97 An kynsa yw an fals a omdhiskwedh Yosef; 98 an nessa yw an fals Sinon Grek a Droia: 99 rag feber tewel aga wra dhe smokya kepar henna."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
100 E l’un di lor, che si recò a noia 101 forse d’esser nomato sì oscuro, 102 col pugno li percosse l’epa croia.
query.result:
**English:**
100 And one of them, who was perhaps annoyed 101 at being named so obscurely, 102 struck him on the hollow of his chest with his fist.
**Cornish:**
100 Ha onan aga, a omdhiskwedh dhe vos dhe vos, 101 mar a-les dhe vos henwys dhe vos, 102 a omlavas aga war an brest gwag.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
103 Quella sonò come fosse un tamburo; 104 e mastro Adamo li percosse il volto 105 col braccio suo, che non parve men duro,
106 dicendo a lui: «Ancor che mi sia tolto 107 lo muover per le membra che son gravi, 108 ho io il braccio a tal mestiere sciolto».
query.result:
**English:**
103 It sounded like a drum; 104 and Master Adam struck him in the face 105 with his arm, which did not seem less hard,
106 saying to him: "Even though I am prevented 107 from moving because of my heavy limbs, 108 I have my arm loosened for such a task."
**Cornish:**
103 Hi a sona kepar tabardh; 104 ha Mestr Adam a omlavas aga war an golwg 105 gans aga bregh, na wra dhe vos mar dowr,
106 ow leveras dh'agan: "Pub tra veur dhe vos kemerys 107 rag dhe gorra dhe vos dhe vos, 108 y'm eus ow bregh dhe vos dhe vos dhe'n ober ma."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
109 Ond’ ei rispuose: «Quando tu andavi 110 al fuoco, non l’avei tu così presto; 111 ma sì e più l’avei quando coniavi».
query.result:
**English:**
109 And he replied: "When you went 110 to the fire, you did not have it so quickly; 111 but you had it just as much, and more, when you were minting coins."
**Cornish:**
109 Ha henna a leveris: "Pandra vea 110 dhe'n tan, nyns esa genen kemmys; 111 mes kemmys ha moy a'n esa pan esa ow konia."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
112 E l’idropico: «Tu di’ ver di questo: 113 ma tu non fosti sì ver testimonio 114 là ’ve del ver fosti a Troia richesto».
query.result:
**English:**
112 And the dropsical man: "You speak truly about this: 113 but you were not so truthful a witness 114 when you were asked for the truth at Troy."
**Cornish:**
112 Ha'n den hidropik: "Gwir a leveris a-dro dhe'n: 113 mes nyns esa genen kemmys gwir a dysti 114 le may fe a vynnis gwir dhe'n Troia."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
115 «S’io dissi falso, e tu falsasti il conio», 116 disse Sinon; «e son qui per un fallo, 117 e tu per più ch’alcun altro demonio!».
query.result:
**English:**
115 "If I spoke falsely, then you falsified the coinage," 116 said Sinon; "and I am here for one fault, 117 and you for more than any other devil!"
**Cornish:**
115 "Ma'th leveris gel, ha thus a vynnis an konia," 116 a leveris Sinon; "ha'm eus ama ow kul ow fal, 117 ha thus rag moy ages an pub den arall!"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
118 «Ricorditi, spergiuro, del cavallo», 119 rispuose quel ch’avëa infiata l’epa; 120 «e sieti reo che tutto il mondo sallo!».
query.result:
**English:**
118 "Remember, perjurer, the horse," 119 replied he who had his belly swollen; 120 "and may you be punished, for all the world knows it!"
**Cornish:**
118 "Koweth, spergiuro, an cheval," 119 a leveris henna a'n esa ow inflata an epa; 120 "ha bos re dhe'n oll an bys a'n gwŷs!"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
121 «E te sia rea la sete onde ti crepa», 122 disse ’l Greco, «la lingua, e l’acqua marcia 123 che ’l ventre innanzi a li occhi sì t’assiepa!».
query.result:
**English:**
121 "And may the thirst that bursts you be evil to you," 122 said the Greek, "and your tongue, and the foul water 123 that makes your belly swell up before your eyes!"
**Cornish:**
121 "Ha bos re dhe'n set owth a'th krep," 122 a leveris an Grek, "an tavos, ha'n dowr martha 123 owth a'th assiepa an ventra rag dhe'n daul!"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
124 Allora il monetier: «Così si squarcia 125 la bocca tua per tuo mal come suole; 126 ché, s’i’ ho sete e omor mi rinfarcia,
127 tu hai l’arsura e ’l capo che ti duole, 128 e per leccar lo specchio di Narcisso, 129 non vorresti a ’nvitar molte parole».
query.result:
**English:**
124 Then the counterfeiter: "Your mouth is torn open 125 for your own evil, as is its wont; 126 for if I am thirsty and hunger torments me,
127 you have the burning and the headache, 128 and to lick Narcissus' mirror, 129 you would not want to invite many words."
**Cornish:**
124 An lavar an monetier: "Kepar hyn a squarcia 125 an boka dhe'n rag dhe'n drok dhe'n, kepar ow syw; 126 rag, ma'm eus set ha owmar a'm rinfarcia,
127 thus owth an arsowra ha'n ben owth a'th dola, 128 ha rag lecca an speculum a Narcissus, 129 nyns esa owth ow invit moy lavar."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
130 Ad ascoltarli er’ io del tutto fisso, 131 quando ’l maestro mi disse: «Or pur mira, 132 che per poco che teco non mi risso!».
query.result:
**English:**
130 I was completely absorbed in listening to them, 131 when the master said to me: "Now just look, 132 for I nearly quarrel with you!"
**Cornish:**
130 Rag dhe'n klevs henna esa ow fis, 131 pan a leveris an mester: "Wella mira, 132 rag rag moy dhe'n risso genen!"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
133 Quand’ io ’l senti’ a me parlar con ira, 134 volsimi verso lui con tal vergogna, 135 ch’ancor per la memoria mi si gira.
query.result:
**English:**
133 When I heard him speak to me with anger, 134 I turned to him with such shame, 135 that even now the memory makes me tremble.
**Cornish:**
133 Pythegowsavynedhagovynomedhgans, 134 ythtroys vythynedhaganevgans, 135 hennagowynomedhgans ytholl vythynedha.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
136 Qual è colui che suo dannaggio sogna, 137 che sognando desidera sognare, 138 sì che quel ch’è, come non fosse, agogna,
139 tal mi fec’ io, non possendo parlare, 140 che disïava scusarmi, e scusava 141 me tuttavia, e nol mi credea fare.
query.result:
**English:**
136 Like one who dreams of his own misfortune, 137 and in his dream longs to be dreaming, 138 so that what is, he desires as if it were not,
139 so I became, unable to speak, 140 desiring to excuse myself, and yet excusing 141 myself all the while, and not believing that I was doing so.
**Cornish:**
136 Kepar ha nen a wraga y golledhans, 137 hag y'n golgow wraga golgow, 138 marow henna nans yw, kepar nag o,
139 hemma wrug vy, heb gallos kewsel, 140 owthynna omdhyskows, hag omdhyskows 141 vy hedre, heb kredis ow tos omma.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
142 «Maggior difetto men vergogna lava», 143 disse ’l maestro, «che ’l tuo non è stato; 144 però d’ogne trestizia ti disgrava.
query.result:
**English:**
142 “A greater fault washes away my shame,” 143 said the master, “than yours has been; 144 therefore, relieve yourself of all sorrow.
**Cornish:**
142 “Morryans gwella a wraga vy golledh,” 143 a leveris an mester, “nagas dha dhyskyblans; 144 rag henna, dilivra vy a bub tristys.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
145 E fa ragion ch’io ti sia sempre allato, 146 se più avvien che fortuna t’accoglia 147 dove sien genti in simigliante piato:
148 ché voler ciò udire è bassa voglia».
query.result:
**English:**
145 And it is right that I should always be at your side, 146 if fortune should ever again bring you 147 where there are people in similar strife:
148 for to desire to hear of this is a base desire.
**Cornish:**
145 Hag yw gwir rag vy dhe vos bys vyth bys, 146 mar bythav byth forton a’th dhegemer 147 le mayth pobel yn keth par orth y’n keth pys:
148 rag dhe vos dhe glywys henna yw orth isel.”
